conclusion: To determine if thermal motion becomes more intense from B to C, analyze the P-V diagram and processes.
Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal, B→C is adiabatic as shown by the vertical arrow.
Isothermal processes occur at constant temperature.
From A to B, isothermal expansion occurs with constant temperature, increasing volume, and decreasing pressure.
From C to D, isothermal compression occurs with constant temperature, decreasing volume, and increasing pressure.
Adiabatic processes involve no heat exchange with surroundings.
From B to C, adiabatic compression increases internal energy due to work done on the gas.
According to the first law of thermodynamics, increased internal energy increases temperature.
Thermal motion intensity is directly related to gas temperature.
Temperature increase during adiabatic compression from B to C intensifies thermal motion.
Yes, thermal motion becomes more intense from B to C.
